choices.text: Examine vocal fold mucosa for general health
Evaluate the location, extent, or compression of the stenosis

questions.text: Functions of videostroboscopy includes all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Evaluate the location, extent, or compression of the stenosis. Videostroboscopy is primarily used to examine the motion and appearance of the vocal cords. It is a highly useful tool in the assessment of vocal fold function and structure, particularly in evaluating biomechanical disturbances and anatomical defects in the vocal cords. It helps visualize the mucosal waves, vocal fold vibratory patterns, and any abnormalities in their movement. However, it does not assess stenosis (narrowing of a passage or duct) in terms of location or extent. That would be more relevant to imaging techniques like CT scans or MRI. Incorrect Options: (A) Examine vocal fold mucosa for general health Videostroboscopy is often used to assess the health of the vocal fold mucosa, looking for signs of inflammation, swelling, or abnormalities in the tissue. This is part of its role in evaluating vocal cord conditions. (B) Vocal fold anatomical defects Videostroboscopy is an excellent tool for detecting anatomical defects of the vocal cords, such as nodules, polyps, or lesions. It can help assess their location and impact on vocal fold function. (C) Vocal fold biomechanical disturbances It is also useful in evaluating vocal fold biomechanical disturbances, such as abnormal vibratory patterns, which could be related to paralysis, dysfunction, or other functional disorders of the vocal folds.

questions.text: Upper airway obstruction at glottic region presents as all of the following except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Feeding problems. Upper airway obstruction at the glottic region typically presents with hoarseness, biphasic stridor, and inspiratory stridor. These symptoms are due to the obstruction affecting the airflow through the larynx, which is the primary structure in the glottic region. However, feeding problems are more likely to be associated with obstruction in areas above the glottis (like the nasopharynx or oropharynx) or issues related to swallowing. Feeding problems are not a typical feature of glottic obstruction, which primarily affects breathing and vocalization. Incorrect Options: (A) Biphasic stridor Biphasic stridor is a classic symptom of upper airway obstruction at the glottic region, meaning it occurs during both inspiration and expiration. This happens because the glottic area (including the vocal cords) causes partial obstruction during both phases of the respiratory cycle. (B) Inspiratory stridor Inspiratory stridor is also common in glottic obstruction. It occurs because the obstruction makes it harder to draw air through the narrowed glottis during inspiration, leading to a high-pitched sound during inhalation. (C) Hoarseness Hoarseness or voice changes are another hallmark of glottic obstruction. This occurs due to vocal cord involvement, either from swelling or narrowing, affecting the normal vibratory pattern during phonation.

questions.text: Most common vascular anomaly to cause stridor is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Double Aortic Arch. A double aortic arch is the most common vascular anomaly that causes stridor. It occurs when there are two aortic arches, one on each side of the trachea and esophagus, which can compress these structures. The resulting compression leads to airway obstruction, causing stridor and breathing difficulties, particularly in infants. Incorrect Options: (A) Pulmonary Artery Sling A pulmonary artery sling occurs when the left pulmonary artery originates anomalously from the right side of the heart and passes between the trachea and esophagus, leading to compression of the trachea and causing stridor. While it can cause stridor, it is less common than a double aortic arch. (B) Retro-Esophageal Right Subclavian Artery This condition, where the right subclavian artery arises abnormally and passes behind the esophagus, can also cause esophageal compression but is less frequently associated with stridor compared to a double aortic arch. (C) Right Aortic Arch A right aortic arch occurs when the aortic arch develops on the right side, instead of the usual left side. While this anomaly can also cause vascular compression of the trachea and esophagus, it is less common than the double aortic arch and is less frequently associated with stridor.

questions.text: Most common vascular anomaly to compress aerodigestive tract is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Retro-Esophageal Right Subclavian Artery. The retro-esophageal right subclavian artery is the most common vascular anomaly that compresses both the aerodigestive tract (trachea and esophagus). This anomaly occurs when the right subclavian artery arises abnormally, traveling behind the esophagus and compressing the trachea and esophagus. This compression leads to swallowing difficulties (dysphagia) and respiratory problems, including stridor and airway obstruction, especially in infants. Incorrect Options: (A) Pulmonary Artery Sling A pulmonary artery sling occurs when the left pulmonary artery originates abnormally from the right side of the heart, passing between the trachea and esophagus, causing compression. While it can affect the aerodigestive tract, it is less common than the retro-esophageal right subclavian artery in causing such compression. (C) Right Aortic Arch A right aortic arch is another vascular anomaly that can cause compression of the aerodigestive tract, but it is not as common as the retro-esophageal right subclavian artery. It occurs when the aortic arch is located on the right side of the trachea and esophagus, leading to potential airway obstruction, but it is less frequently involved in compression of both the trachea and esophagus. (D) Double Aortic Arch A double aortic arch is a congenital condition in which two arches form, one on each side of the trachea and esophagus. This can compress the aerodigestive tract and cause airway obstruction. Although it is a significant cause of stridor, it is less common compared to the retro-esophageal right subclavian artery in causing compression of both the trachea and esophagus.

questions.text: Nocturnal stridor and respiratory distress with normal head and neck exam favours the diagnosis of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Acute Spasmodic Laryngitis. Acute Spasmodic Laryngitis is a condition that commonly affects young children, typically presenting with nocturnal stridor and respiratory distress, often during the night. The key feature of this condition is that it often appears suddenly and can cause stridor and difficulty breathing without any other signs of infection or inflammation when examined. The normal head and neck exam further supports this diagnosis, as there is no visible swelling or abnormality of the larynx or other structures. Incorrect Options: (A) Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup) Croup is characterized by a barking cough, hoarseness, and stridor, typically caused by viral infections such as parainfluenza. Although it may cause nocturnal symptoms, it is usually accompanied by a fever and general malaise, and the examination often shows signs of laryngeal inflammation or swelling, which is absent in spasmodic laryngitis. (B) Acute Supraglottitis Acute supraglottitis is a potentially life-threatening infection characterized by fever, drooling, and difficulty swallowing. It is typically seen with stridor and respiratory distress, but it also presents with significant inflammation and swelling of the supraglottic structures, making it unlikely to present with a normal head and neck exam. The onset of supraglottitis is more insidious compared to spasmodic laryngitis. (D) Acute Epiglottitis Acute epiglottitis is also a serious condition that causes severe respiratory distress and stridor. It is usually accompanied by fever, drooling, and difficulty swallowing, and examination often reveals swelling of the epiglottis. The normal head and neck exam seen in spasmodic laryngitis would not be consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from bilateral abductor spasmodic dysphonia. What type of voice is expected in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Breathy voice. Bilateral abductor spasmodic dysphonia involves spasms of the muscles that control vocal fold abduction (separating the vocal cords). This causes difficulty in keeping the vocal cords apart, leading to incomplete closure of the vocal cords during speech. As a result, air escapes during phonation, which leads to a breathy voice. The patient may have difficulty producing sound with the appropriate intensity, leading to a voice that sounds weak or breathy. Incorrect Options: (B) Strangulated voice A strangulated voice is typically seen in adductor spasmodic dysphonia, where the vocal cords spasm together, resulting in voice breaks or interruptions in speech. This is quite the opposite of a breathy voice, which occurs when the vocal cords do not come together properly. (C) Hot potato voice A hot potato voice is characterized by a muffled, nasal tone, often seen in conditions like upper airway obstruction or tonsillitis. It is caused by difficulty in properly articulating words due to an obstructed or swollen oral or nasal cavity. This is not related to abductor spasmodic dysphonia. (D) Aphonia Aphonia refers to the complete loss of voice, where no sound can be produced. In abductor spasmodic dysphonia, there may still be some degree of voice production, but it will be breathy and weak, rather than absent.

questions.text: Androphonia can be corrected by doing:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Type 4 Thyroplasty. Androphonia is a condition where a female voice sounds unnaturally high-pitched or prepubescent, typically caused by insufficient vibratory length and tension of the vocal cords. Type 4 Thyroplasty is specifically designed to lower the pitch of the voice, often used to treat individuals with androphonia, by adjusting the tension of the vocal cords. This procedure involves implanting a material in the thyroid cartilage to modify the vocal fold position and tension, making the voice sound deeper. Incorrect Options: (A) Type 1 Thyroplasty Type 1 Thyroplasty is performed to treat unilateral vocal cord paralysis, where the goal is to move the paralyzed vocal cord closer to the midline to improve voice quality. It is not typically used for lowering the pitch in androphonia. (B) Type 2 Thyroplasty Type 2 Thyroplasty is used to increase the tension of the vocal cords, which is typically done in cases of vocal cord paralysis or weakness where there is a need to improve the loudness or quality of the voice. It is not used for lowering the pitch in androphonia. (C) Type 3 Thyroplasty Type 3 Thyroplasty is used for vocal cord insufficiency, where a posterior medialization is performed to help with increasing voice volume. It does not address lowering the pitch, which is required in androphonia.

choices.text: Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube
Suction of tube with sodium bicarbonate

questions.text: A tracheostomized patient, with portex tracheostomy tube, in the ward, developed sudden complete blockage of the tube. What will be the best next step for the management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube. In the case of sudden complete blockage of a tracheostomy tube, the best immediate action is to remove the tracheostomy tube as quickly as possible. This allows for re-establishing the airway by either replacing the tube or performing an emergency airway intervention (e.g., using a catheter or performing a cricothyroidotomy if necessary). The obstruction may be caused by a mucous plug, a kink in the tube, or a tube that has become displaced or blocked, and quick action is crucial to restore normal breathing. Incorrect Options: (B) Suction of tube with sodium bicarbonate Suctioning the tube with sodium bicarbonate is not a common or recommended practice for managing a complete blockage of a tracheostomy tube. If suction is required, it would typically be done with sterile saline to help loosen mucus plugs or secretions, but this does not address a complete obstruction where immediate tube removal is necessary. (C) Suction of tube with saline Suctioning with saline might help in some cases of partial blockage due to mucus but may not be effective in a complete blockage. In such a situation, the tracheostomy tube must be removed to clear the airway and restore breathing. Suctioning alone is not sufficient for a complete blockage. (D) Jet ventilation Jet ventilation might be used in certain emergency airway situations where there is a need to ventilate the patient but cannot be a substitute for addressing the actual cause of the blockage (e.g., removing the tracheostomy tube or replacing it). It is not the first-line step in managing complete obstruction of a tracheostomy tube.

questions.text: Dead space is reduced in tracheotomy:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 30-50%. Tracheotomy involves the creation of an opening in the trachea to establish an airway. One of the key physiological benefits of a tracheotomy is the reduction in dead space within the respiratory system. Dead space refers to the portion of the respiratory system where no gas exchange occurs, such as the nose, mouth, pharynx, and trachea up to the site of the gas exchange (alveoli). In patients with a tracheotomy, the upper airway dead space is bypassed, leading to a significant reduction in the overall dead space. A reduction of 30-50% in dead space is commonly observed due to the bypassing of the upper airways, especially in patients with chronic respiratory conditions or those requiring long-term ventilation support. This reduction helps improve the efficiency of ventilation. Incorrect Options: (A) 15% The reduction in dead space is typically much higher than 15% in most patients who undergo tracheotomy, especially those with long-term respiratory conditions. The reduction of dead space is usually reported as 30-50%, making 15% too low. (C) 10% A 10% reduction in dead space is also too low compared to what is typically seen in tracheotomy patients. The actual reduction is generally much higher than this. (D) 20% A 20% reduction is still below the typical range seen in patients with tracheotomies, as the reduction in dead space is usually in the 30-50% range.

questions.text: Microlaryngoscopy is usually done with an objective lens with focal length of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 400 mm. Microlaryngoscopy is a procedure used to examine the larynx using a microscope or an endoscopic camera system, often with the assistance of a microscope. The goal is to assess the vocal cords and surrounding structures for any abnormalities or pathologies. The objective lens used in microlaryngoscopy typically has a focal length of 400 mm. This focal length allows for a clear, magnified view of the larynx, facilitating detailed examination and surgical intervention when necessary. Incorrect Options: (A) 200 mm A focal length of 200 mm is too short for a high-quality microlaryngoscopy. This would provide a closer but less detailed view, which is not typically suitable for the level of magnification required during the procedure. (C) 100 mm A 100 mm focal length would produce an even closer and more magnified view, but it would compromise the depth of field and overall image clarity, which is not ideal for microlaryngoscopy. (D) 300 mm While 300 mm is somewhat closer to the correct focal length, it is still less optimal than 400 mm for providing a clear, detailed view of the larynx. It may also reduce the depth of field compared to the 400 mm lens.

questions.text: Patient of presbylaryngis can present with all of the following symptoms except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lower pitch. Presbylaryngis refers to age-related changes in the larynx, which include degeneration of the vocal fold structures and muscle tone, leading to a variety of symptoms that affect the voice. The symptoms of presbylaryngis typically include: Hoarse-breathy voice: Due to thinning of the vocal folds and reduced muscle tone. Voice tremors: A common sign due to weakened control of the vocal fold muscles. Voice fatigue: The vocal cords become less resilient, and prolonged use can lead to vocal fatigue or strain. Lower pitch is not typically seen in presbylaryngis. Instead, due to the thinning of the vocal folds and the weakening of the supporting muscles, the voice tends to become higher-pitched or breathy as the vocal folds lose mass and elasticity, causing a shallow or thin quality to the voice. Incorrect Options: (A) Hoarse-breathy voice This is a common symptom of presbylaryngis, as the vocal folds become thinner and less flexible with age, leading to a hoarse, breathy voice. (C) Voice tremors As muscle control of the larynx weakens with age, some individuals develop tremors or a shaking quality in their voice. (D) Voice fatigue Due to reduced vocal fold strength and elasticity, individuals with presbylaryngis often experience vocal fatigue after speaking for extended periods.

questions.text: Gutzmann’s pressure test is related with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Puberphonia. Gutzmann’s pressure test is a diagnostic test used in puberphonia (also known as mutational falsetto), a condition in which a post-pubertal individual, typically male, continues to use a higher-pitched voice that is more common in childhood, instead of adopting a lower adult voice after puberty. Gutzmann’s pressure test involves applying pressure over the laryngeal region (specifically over the thyroid cartilage). In individuals with puberphonia, this test may result in a lower pitch when pressure is applied, helping confirm the diagnosis. The test is based on the premise that puberphonia is due to inappropriate tension in the vocal cords and that with the application of pressure, the vocal cords relax, leading to a more typical, lower pitch. Incorrect Options: (B) Phonasthenia Phonasthenia is a voice disorder characterized by voice fatigue, weak voice, or loss of vocal strength, but it is not specifically associated with Gutzmann’s pressure test. (C) Conversion Disorders Conversion disorders involve neurological symptoms (such as paralysis, tremors, or non-epileptic seizures) that occur without a clear physical cause, often linked to psychological stress. Gutzmann’s pressure test is not related to conversion disorders. (D) Plica Ventricularis Plica ventricularis refers to the ventricular folds (false vocal cords), which can become involved in voice disorders, but Gutzmann’s pressure test is not related to this condition.

questions.text: Faulty use of false vocal folds leads to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Plica Ventricularis. Faulty use of the false vocal folds (also known as the ventricular folds) can lead to plica ventricularis. This condition occurs when the false vocal cords are used inappropriately for phonation, instead of the true vocal cords, leading to abnormal voice production. This may result in a voice that is hoarse, strained, or rough, and it can also contribute to vocal fatigue or discomfort. The false vocal folds (or ventricular folds) are normally not used for sound production. When they are activated improperly for phonation, it results in plica ventricularis. Incorrect Options: (A) Puberphonia Puberphonia (mutational falsetto) is a condition where an individual continues to use a high-pitched voice after puberty, which is not directly related to faulty use of the false vocal folds. It is usually due to psychological or developmental factors rather than misuse of the false vocal folds. (B) Phonasthenia Phonasthenia refers to a condition of voice fatigue or weakness, often resulting from overuse or misuse of the voice. While misuse of the false vocal folds can contribute to a weak voice, phonasthenia itself is a broader term and not specifically related to faulty use of the false vocal folds. (C) Conversion Disorders Conversion disorders involve neurological symptoms, such as paralysis or non-epileptic seizures, that do not have a physical cause but are related to psychological stress. It is not linked to faulty use of the false vocal folds or voice disorders like plica ventricularis.

questions.text: Tracheostomy was done in a old male child diagnosed as case of congenital subglottis stenosis. As a ENT surgeon you advice the parents of child for regular endoscope every:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 3 months. In a case of congenital subglottic stenosis where a tracheostomy has been performed, regular monitoring through endoscopy is essential to assess the condition of the airway and determine if there are any changes, such as worsening stenosis or complications. In such cases, endoscopic examination every 3 months is typically advised to monitor the airway’s status and to evaluate if further interventions, such as surgery or dilation, are necessary. Incorrect Options: (A) 1 month A follow-up every 1 month is generally not required unless there are signs of rapid progression or severe complications. It may be too frequent for routine monitoring unless there are specific concerns. (B) 2 months A 2-month interval may also be too short for routine surveillance in most cases of congenital subglottic stenosis. While it’s important to monitor, 3 months is typically sufficient for assessing the condition without overburdening the child with excessive procedures. (D) 6 months A 6-month interval may be too long between endoscopic evaluations in children with congenital subglottic stenosis, especially in the early years, as the condition may change over time. 3 months is generally the recommended timeframe to ensure timely intervention if needed.

choices.text: Tubes are made up of silver alloy and titanium
Metal tubes are ideally changed every 3 days
Cuffed tubes are used for IPPV

questions.text: All are true about tracheostomy tube except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Metal tubes are ideally changed every 3 days. In fact, metal tracheostomy tubes are not typically changed every 3 days. They are made of durable materials such as silver alloy or titanium and can often remain in place for a longer period (sometimes weeks or even months), depending on the condition of the patient and the tube. Frequent changing is not necessary unless there are specific complications like infection or obstruction. Incorrect Options: (A) Consists of two metallic tubes A metal tracheostomy tube often consists of two tubes: an inner tube (which can be removed and cleaned) and an outer tube that remains in place in the trachea. (B) Tubes are made up of silver alloy and titanium Silver alloy and titanium are commonly used in the construction of metal tracheostomy tubes due to their strength, biocompatibility, and resistance to corrosion. (D) Cuffed tubes are used for IPPV Cuffed tracheostomy tubes are typically used when invasive positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) is needed. The cuff helps create a seal in the trachea to prevent air from escaping and to ensure adequate ventilation.

questions.text: Elliptical space between the cords is seen in cases of weakness of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thyroarytenoid. The thyroarytenoid muscle plays a crucial role in the adduction of the vocal cords and in maintaining their tension. When there is weakness or paralysis of this muscle, it can result in a gap between the vocal cords, particularly in the elliptical space or glottic gap during phonation. Incorrect Options: (B) Interarytenoid The interarytenoid muscle also aids in adducting the vocal cords, but its dysfunction typically results in difficulty closing the vocal cords during phonation. This may cause vocal weakness but is less associated with an elliptical space. (C) Both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid Weakness in both muscles could lead to glottic insufficiency, but it would not be the primary cause of an elliptical space between the cords. Weakness of the thyroarytenoid muscle alone is more likely to cause the specific appearance of an elliptical space. (D) None This option would be incorrect as weakness of the thyroarytenoid muscle is a well-established cause of the elliptical space between the vocal cords.

questions.text: A construction worker met with an accident and presented to the trauma centre when a heavy concrete block fell over his face. He was found to have severe maxillofacial and laryngeal injury. He was not able to open his mouth and, on examination, he is found to have multiple fractures and obstruction in patent airway, the following procedure was done for him. Which of the following options correct define the procedure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cricothyroidotomy. In this case, the patient has sustained severe maxillofacial and laryngeal injuries, which have resulted in an obstruction in the patent airway and an inability to open the mouth. Given these conditions, a cricothyroidotomy would be the most appropriate emergency procedure to secure the airway. Cricothyroidotomy involves making an incision through the cricothyroid membrane to establish an airway when other methods of securing the airway, such as orotracheal intubation, are not possible due to facial or laryngeal trauma. This procedure is especially indicated in situations of severe facial trauma where access to the mouth or nose is compromised. Incorrect Options: (A) Submental endotracheal intubation This technique involves placing an endotracheal tube through a submental incision, providing an airway when there is maxillofacial trauma. However, it is not the most common or immediate procedure performed in cases of airway obstruction due to traumatic injury. A cricothyroidotomy is preferred when rapid airway access is needed. (B) Emergency tracheostomy An emergency tracheostomy is typically performed when prolonged airway management is needed, or if other less invasive procedures have failed. However, cricothyroidotomy is preferred in the acute setting due to its faster execution and lower complication rate compared to tracheostomy. (D) Subcutaneous tracheostomy This is an uncommon procedure and not typically used in emergency airway management. A subcutaneous tracheostomy would involve placing a tracheostomy tube beneath the skin, but this is not the standard technique in traumatic airway obstructions where cricothyroidotomy is preferred.

choices.text: A patient of vocal cord palsy scheduled for thyroplasty
A patient of caner larynx scheduled for laryngectomy

questions.text: In which of the following case high-level tracheostomy is preferred?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A patient of cancer larynx scheduled for laryngectomy. A high-level tracheostomy is typically performed in patients who are undergoing laryngectomy (surgical removal of the larynx). This procedure is done to ensure that the patient can breathe through the tracheostomy after the larynx is removed. The tracheostomy is placed high in the neck, usually above the level of the stoma (opening) created during the laryngectomy, to help with respiratory function and maintain airway patency following the procedure. It is particularly beneficial in cases where the airway is at risk due to the removal of the vocal cords and laryngeal structures. Incorrect Options: (A) Foreign body obstruction in trachea A low tracheostomy or an emergency cricothyroidotomy would be more appropriate for managing airway obstruction caused by a foreign body in the trachea. A high-level tracheostomy would not be typically preferred for this type of acute obstruction. (B) A patient of vocal cord palsy scheduled for thyroplasty Thyroplasty is a procedure done to improve vocal cord function in patients with vocal cord paralysis, typically involving surgical alteration of the thyroid cartilage. This is not an indication for a high-level tracheostomy, as the procedure does not involve the removal of the larynx, and airway management is usually handled with standard intubation or tracheostomy at a lower level if needed. (D) A child with acute epiglottitis Acute epiglottitis involves inflammation and potential obstruction of the supraglottic structures, but high-level tracheostomy is not commonly the procedure of choice. In such cases, endotracheal intubation or, if necessary, a low tracheostomy may be performed. The airway management focuses on securing the airway as quickly as possible, usually in a lower, safer region.

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is seen in which of the following lesions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Supra glottic Inspiratory stridor is a high-pitched sound during inhalation and is usually indicative of an obstruction in the upper airway. This includes areas like the supraglottic region, which is the area above the vocal cords. Supraglottic lesions (e.g., tumors, infections, swelling) cause inspiratory stridor because they obstruct the airway before the vocal cords, making it harder for air to enter the trachea during inspiration. Incorrect Options: (B) Subglottic Subglottic lesions typically cause expiratory stridor because the obstruction is below the vocal cords. This creates difficulty in exhaling air out of the trachea. Subglottic stenosis or other issues below the vocal cords will result in expiratory rather than inspiratory stridor. (C) Tracheal Lesions in the trachea (such as tracheal stenosis or tumors) can cause both inspiratory and expiratory stridor depending on the location of the obstruction. The stridor may be biphasic (heard during both inhalation and exhalation), but typically, inspiratory stridor is not the hallmark symptom unless the lesion is specifically in the upper trachea near the vocal cords. (D) Bronchial Bronchial obstructions affect the lower airways (below the trachea), and they often lead to symptoms like wheezing or difficulty breathing but not typically inspiratory stridor. Bronchial lesions cause more of an expiratory or wheezing sound due to obstruction of airflow in the bronchi.
